title: Euler's Generalization of Fermat's Little Theorem
description: For coprime integers a and n, a^φ(n) ≡ 1 (mod n), where φ(n) is Euler's totient function. This generalizes Fermat's Little Theorem.

meta.author: Euler (formalized in Lean 4 with Mathlib)

Multiple formulations for different use cases

overview.historicalContext: Euler published this generalization in 1763. It extends Fermat's Little Theorem (1640) from prime moduli to arbitrary positive integers. The theorem is fundamental to RSA cryptography.
overview.problemStatement:
**Euler's Theorem**:

For n > 0 and gcd(a, n) = 1:
$$a^{\varphi(n)} \equiv 1 \pmod{n}$$

where φ(n) counts integers 1 ≤ k ≤ n that are coprime to n.
overview.proofStrategy: The multiplicative group (ℤ/nℤ)* has order φ(n), so by Lagrange's theorem any element raised to the group order equals the identity.
keyInsights: Fermat's Little Theorem is the special case when n is prime

conclusion.summary: Euler's theorem is verified using group theory, with Fermat's Little Theorem as a natural corollary.
